title: 109_s2695
content: The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 aims to make research findings funded by the Federal Government accessible to the public. Congress recognizes the importance of sharing research results to advance science and benefit society. The Act emphasizes the role of the Internet in providing easy access to this information for scientists, educators, and citizens. The Federal Research Public Access Act defines a "Federal agency" as an Executive agency under title 5, United States Code. The Federal Research Public Access Act requires Federal agencies with over $100,000,000 in research expenditures to develop a policy for public access to research papers funded by the government. This policy includes submitting the author's final manuscript of research papers accepted for publication in peer-reviewed journals. The Federal Research Public Access Act mandates that Federal agencies with significant research expenditures create a policy for public access to research papers funded by the government. This policy involves submitting the author's final manuscript of accepted research papers for publication in peer-reviewed journals, incorporating changes from peer review, and replacing the final manuscript with the published version if certain conditions are met. The Federal Research Public Access Act requires Federal agencies to provide free online public access to final peer-reviewed manuscripts or published versions within 6 months of publication. Additionally, agencies must create an online bibliography linking to the full text of publicly accessible research papers. The Federal Research Public Access Act mandates Federal agencies to ensure free online public access to final peer-reviewed manuscripts within 6 months of publication. This includes creating an online bibliography linking to the full text of publicly accessible research papers and preserving published research findings in a stable digital repository for long-term free public access. The Federal Research Public Access Act requires Federal agencies to provide free online public access to final peer-reviewed manuscripts within 6 months of publication. This includes storing research papers in a digital repository with free public access, interoperability, and long-term preservation. The policy applies to researchers employed or funded by the Federal agency, ensuring their works are accessible to the public. The Federal Research Public Access Act mandates that works by researchers employed or funded by Federal agencies be marked as public domain material when published and made immediately available online. It also emphasizes the use of Government licenses for reproduction and other purposes of final manuscripts for Federal use. The Federal Research Public Access Act requires works by researchers employed or funded by Federal agencies to be marked as public domain when published online. It also emphasizes the use of Government licenses for reproduction of final manuscripts for Federal use. Exclusions include laboratory notes, preliminary data analyses, and classified research. The Federal Research Public Access Act requires works by researchers employed or funded by Federal agencies to be marked as public domain when published online. Exclusions include classified research, works generating revenue, and authors who do not submit their work to journals. This Act does not affect any rights under patent or copyright law. The Federal Research Public Access Act excludes works rejected by journals and does not impact rights under patent or copyright law. Federal agencies must submit an annual report on their research public access policy to specific committees in Congress. The Federal Research Public Access Act requires federal agencies to submit an annual report on their research public access policy to specific committees in Congress, including the Governmental Affairs of the Senate, the Committee on Government Reform of the House of Representatives, and any other relevant committee. Each report must assess the effectiveness of the policy in providing free online access to research papers funded by the agency. The Federal Research Public Access Act mandates federal agencies to provide free online access to research papers funded by the agency, including a list of papers published in peer-reviewed journals and a corresponding list of papers available through the agency's online repository. The agency must also report on the time between public availability of papers in journals and the online repository. The Federal agency is required to provide free online access to research papers funded by the agency, including lists of papers published in journals and available in the agency's online repository. They must also report on the time between public availability of papers in journals and the online repository.
